Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Combinatorial Online Learning and its Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Several important problems in machine learning, such as maximum
aposteriori (MAP) inference in graphical models, are inherently combinatorial. While extensive research has been devoted to designing approximation algorithms for such problems, existing algorithms do not scale well to large problems. This project focuses on leveraging ideas from online learning with expert advice to develop a novel family of online learning algorithms for combinatorial optimization problems.

Algorithms for combinatorial online learning are efficient and simple to analyze in order to establish guarantees. Unlike existing literature on approximation algorithms for combinatorial problems which rely on suitable real relaxations of the original problem, combinatorial online learning algorithms never use relaxations; they work directly with binary/integer solutions and have global approximation guarantees. The project investigates generalizations of the framework to solve online and batch binary quadratic programming problems, yielding approximation algorithms for a variety of combinatorial problems, including NP-complete problems, and MAP inference in directed and undirected graphical models. The project considers three important real life applications: portfolio selection for effectively investing in the stock market, automating surgical pathology by expediting disease detection in tissue images, and climate change detection for discovering abrupt climate changes from spatiotemporal climate data.

The project is expected to be transformative, especially in the context of surgical pathology and climate change detection, yielding significant long term societal benefits. The research results will be disseminated to the community through research papers, tutorials, open source software, and outreach activities using games based on mock stock markets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several real world applications of machine learning, such as sparse regression and inference in graphical models, need to solve structured or combinatorial problems. Such problems need to be solved with large scale batch data and increasingly with data being accumulated over time, which corresponds to the online learning setting in machine learning. The project focused on developing efficient algorithms for solving such problems and also illustrating the benefits of such algorithms in a variety of real world problems including social media analytics, finance and portfolio selection, analysis of spatial data from climate science, and applications in surgical pathology. The ideas and algorithms developed in the project have found applications in other projects being pursued by other research groups, including recent work in structured learning and deep reinforcement learning, among others.

In the context of the project, key technical advances were made and new algorithms were developed in the context of the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) framework. While ADMMs have been around since the 1970s, they have become popular over the last decade due to their ability to do parallel optimization by variable splitting for large scale problems. Our work contributed to both improving our understanding of the ADMM family of algorithms and generalizing the idea to new settings notably including (i) OADM (online alternating direction method) for solving online linear/convex optimization problems with linear constraints, (ii) Bethe ADMM for efficient parallel MAP (maximum aposteriori) inference in graphical models, (iii) Bregman ADMM for more flexible and scalable iterative updates based on general divergences, (iv) PDMM (parallel direction method of multipliers) for parallel block updates for multi-block constraints, and (v) A2DM2 (accelerated ADMM), which incorporates Nesterov acceleration for faster convergence of ADMMs. Our work has also contributed to ideas specific to online learning and online optimization, notable including (i) lazy updates for online gradient descent and related methods where parameters are updated infrequently leading to stability and scalability, (ii) online meta-algorithms for combining predictions from multiple online learning algorithms, and (iii) trading off risk and reward over time based on hedging and related ideas. We have also developed algorithms for learning statistical dependencies in multivariate settings, and applied such ideas to high-dimensional multivariate Gaussian and Gaussian copula distributions. Such advances constitute the core technical contributions of the work.

The technical and algorithmic advances have been applied to a variety of real world application domains. Detecting novel and emerging topics from social media streams is an important problem in social media analytics, but the volume and velocity of such streams make the problem challenging. We developed a novel approach for the task based on non-smooth regression, and illustrated the effectiveness of the approach with experiments on real data from twitter. We used portfolio selection as an example sequential decision making problem, and illustrated the effectiveness of several of our proposed algorithms in this domain. In particular, we illustrated how OADM and variants can be used to trade-off risk and rewards in portfolio selection with streaming data, how lazy updates imply conservative trading saving commission costs, and how structured hedging can be an effective strategy for such sequential multivariate decision making problems. We have also applied the ideas in the context of climate science, in particular the formation of effective multi-model ensembles which can combine predictions from multiple climate models across space possibly weighing the models differently at different spatial locations based on their skills. The problem was formulated as a multi-task learning (MTL) problem, with each location corresponding to a task, and we developed models and methods for learning task dependencies. The MTL formulation for climate model ensembles with task dependency learning was shown to outperform several baselines, and the overall idea was shown to be competitive in several MTL problems.
